text: Has anyone had a positive or negative experience with doing rev-share with a client? I've got a long-term client who is considering launching new products/services based on the traffic we've helped them build, and they asked if we'd be open to a revenue sharing model. On the surface, I don't hate the idea — we have long-term buy-in from the client, and we trust them. But I'm curious what it's actually like in practice to share revenue rather than follow a standard pay-for-services model. Any and all input is welcome!

text:
Hi all! I'm not sure if this is the right forum for this, but what the heck :shrug::skin-tone-2:

I work in CX by day and do freelance content writing by night (for ~4 years now). I recently had a CX company I've written for ask if I'm interested in going in-house and working with them full-time on content creation and evangelization.

It's an intriguing idea, but since I don't have a marketing background it's honestly hard for me to imagine what that would look like.

Can anyone share resources or their experience around what day-to-day or week-to-week looks like in a role like that?

Thanks in advance!

Thanks in advance!

text:
Hi hi! Would you be doing revenue sharing or profit sharing?

I once debated profit sharing with a client but ended up turning it down due to lack of reliability. It was too risky for me due to my fixed costs (tools, subcontractors, etc) potentially outweighing the payout I received after my client paid out their expenses. Just my experience though!

elements.text:

I once debated profit sharing with a client but ended up turning it down due to lack of reliability. It was too risky for me due to my fixed costs (tools, subcontractors, etc) potentially outweighing the payout I received after my client paid out their expenses. Just my experience though!

text: Totally makes sense! To answer the question, he posed it as revenue sharing rather than profit sharing. I'm a novice here, so I don't know much about the difference between the two (although they seem somewhat self-explanatory).
